unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Significance of Dunkin Bucks
question_text: Dunkin Bucks is interested if there is a significant difference in the number of cups of coffee their adult customers drink per day compared with their teenage customers. Dunkin Bucks randomly selects $10\text{ adults}$ and $10\text{ teenagers}$ and asks them: "How many cups of coffee do you drink?" The resulting data is below: N Average cups Standard Deviation Adults $10$ $1.8$ $0.6$ Teenagers $10$ $1.3$ $0.3$ $$  $$ T-test of $ { \mu  }_{ Adults }-{ \mu  }_{ Children }=0$ T-value = $2.357$ P-value = $0.034$ Degrees of Freedom = $13.235$ What conclusion can be made based on these results?

choices.text: There is sufficient evidence of a difference between the average number of cups of coffee an adult drinks compared to a teenager at the 1 % 1 % significance level, but not at the 5 % 5 % and 10 % 10 % significance levels.

There is sufficient evidence of a difference between the average number of cups of coffee an adult drinks compared to a teenager at the 1 % 1 % and 5 % 5 % significance levels, but not the 10 % 10 % significance level.
There is sufficient evidence of a difference between the average number of cups of coffee an adult drinks compared to a teenager at the 1 % 1 % , 5 % 5 % , and 10 % 10 % significance levels.

There is insufficient evidence of a difference between the average number of cups of coffee an adult drinks compared to a teenager at the 1 % 1 % significance level, but not the 5 % 5 % and 10 % 10 % significance levels.

There is insufficient evidence of a difference between the average number of cups of coffee an adult drinks compared to a teenager at the 1 % 1 % significance level and 5 % 5 % significance level, but not the 10 % 10 % significance level.
